title: Brownhill Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Stephen Craven / Brownhill Reservoir
images.caption: Brownhill Reservoir. Brownhill dam was built in the 1930s. When this reservoir is full, the long-term settlement of the earth dam can be clearly seen (follow the line of the bottom of the wave wall, compared with the water surface which must be horizontal). In the middle distance is the valve tower, and the buildings on the far side are the water treatment works.

images.title: Brownhill Reservoir by Stevie D, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Brownhill Reservoir

images.title: Towards Brownhill Reservoir by Chris Wimbush, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Holme Valley countryside above the reservoir.

images.title: Phil Catterall / Northern end of Ramsden Reservoir
images.caption: Northern end of Ramsden Reservoir

description: This walk visits Brownhill Reservoir near Holmfirth. There's a car park at the southern end of the water where you can start your walk. You can then follow footpaths heading down towards the dam and the adjacent Ramsden Reservoir. There's also a nice country lane running to the east of the lakes. The path sits above the two reservoirs providing fine views down to the two picturesque bodies of water. It's suitable for walkers or cyclists and name Brownhill Lane.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Kirklees Way and the Holme Valley Circular Walk both run past the site. You could pick up these waymarked trails to visit the nearby Digley Reservoir and Holme Styes Reservoir. To the south west there's the Yateholme Reservoir, Holme Moss transmitter and Wilmer Hill where there are some excellent views to enjoy.

display_address: Brownhill Lane, Holme Valley, Holme, Kirklees, West Yorkshire, England, HD9 2QW, United Kingdom
